posts.post_content:
First, outstanding artwork on this card.  
  
Second, here we have [Fact or Fiction](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Fact or Fiction). To those who aren't familiar with the card or were not involved in the game when Fact or Fiction was a big tournament player, the card is broken.  
  
Fact or Fiction on its own was ![3](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=3&type=symbol)![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol). Subtracting that from the mana cost leaves us with ![2](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=2&type=symbol)![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol) for a 5/6 flier. That seems absurd, but we also must keep in mind that Fact or Fiction was an instant, and this guy is a creature.  
  
No, it's not as powerful as Fact or Fiction. Yes, it is still a monster. It's probably not quite good enough for constructed right now, but there are very few cards I would like to be sitting across from less than this guy in M12 limited.
posts.html:
First, outstanding artwork on this card.

Second, here we have Fact or Fiction. To those who aren't familiar with the card or were not involved in the game when Fact or Fiction was a big tournament player, the card is broken.

Fact or Fiction on its own was . Subtracting that from the mana cost leaves us with for a 5/6 flier. That seems absurd, but we also must keep in mind that Fact or Fiction was an instant, and this guy is a creature.

No, it's not as powerful as Fact or Fiction. Yes, it is still a monster. It's probably not quite good enough for constructed right now, but there are very few cards I would like to be sitting across from less than this guy in M12 limited.

posts.post_content:
Fun card that may see some play if Magic slows down as much as people believe it will once the sets rotate for Innistrad, and maybe even a little before that. If nothing else, it's nice to have a [Fact or Fiction](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Fact or Fiction) that eats [Baneslayer Angel](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Baneslayer Angel)s for breakfast for the next few months.  
  
Also, fabulous artwork.

posts.post_content:
There's a problem with this rule:  
  
------  
9/22/2011 In multiplayer games, you choose an opponent to separate the cards when the ability resolves. This doesn't target that opponent. Because the cards are revealed, all players may see the cards and offer opinions.  
------  
  
In our Commander format some guys just use it to pick THEIR FRIEND which separates it into 5-0 (FIVE-ZERO) piles. So does it really work as intended?  
  
I have read the comments but could not find anyone with the same problem though.
posts.html:

posts.post_content:
Hmm, if I think about cheating this in play with something like [Polymorph](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Polymorph), then a lot better creatures come to mind... And hardcasting this is in mono blue is pretty absurd.  
  
It feels as though at 7 cmc, you should cast something else that actually wins you the game instead of draws you a few cards. I would personally perfer [Consecrated Sphinx](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Consecrated Sphinx) over this since you can pull off a lot more tricks and potentially draw more cards.

Posted By: dberry02 (8/1/2011 9:14:21 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Potentially even better than [Fact or Fiction](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Fact or Fiction) in EDH. Three extra mana for a solid creature that goes great on a [Mimic Vat](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mimic Vat)? Sounds like a fantastic deal in slower formats.  
  
On the other hand, the lower CMC and instant speed of FoF means you get a better chance of doing something fancy with the rest of the mana on that turn, maybe with one of the cards you get, and maybe on your opponent's turn. And for better or for worse, the sphinx is less prone to fancy schmancy redirect effects. Though if you're using one you might want to use the other, so you might not even have to choose between them.
posts.html:
